ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to read, analyze, and form higher level arguments on poetry and literature.
I became a better reader, writer, thinker, and listener.
I learned how to look deeply at American poetry and literature, as well as how to write creative English essays.

This course explored American Literature, especially with regards to the American authors of all kinds. You get to read books like Moby-Dick, which is one I always wanted to read but never got to, and explore poetry in depth. Very cool coverage of course material!

I gained, dare I say, an eye for beauty -- or at least an appreciation for artistry and beauty in the world that I've never fathomed before. We learn to pay particular attention to form in literature, which opens us up to depths of art rich in meaning.

I honed my close-reading skills in assignments that ranged from philology to chapter analysis to a comparison paper, in which I compared an early American poet with a later American novelist. The class underscored themes of nature, race, gender, sexuality, religion, and more as they are woven through the American experience.
I received a survey in American literature, discussing the texts in class as well as writing three essays on various subjects.
improved literart analysis/writing skills

Beyond reading fantastic books from and critical of the American canon, this class honed my discussion skills and made me a better writer and thinker. Each section, the thoughts and critiques of my peers pushed me to deepen my understanding of the books that we were reading, introducing me to new analyses and perspectives with every text. Professor Peters also wrote detailed notes on each of our papers, giving me advice and challenges to address in my next piece of writing. Finally, this class gave me new insights into the American experience, expanding upon the pieces I encountered in high school to broaden and, often, directly confront the "traditional" voices that make up its narrative to question the United States' legacy of enslavement and discrimination and create a more inclusive literature.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The discussion were always pretty interesting and the class was overall very engaged. John Peters was always great at leading discussion and definitely was very passionate about the topic.
Prof. Peters is excellent! The class discussions were so enriching -- it was a joy to go to class every time (even over Zoom)!

Strength: seminar discussions were very helpful, class was very casual and open-minded, literature was classic
Weaknesses: more poetry than I expected from the title of the course
Discussions were always exciting and the topics covered were fascinating. The range of works we read was also great. Wouldnt change a thing, except maybe have it be in person.

The real strength of this course are the people. Professor John Durham Peters is one of the smartest, most loving, and best professors I have ever had -- he is the real gem of this course. Don't take this course because you're into the books listed on the syllabus, take it to experience even a few tastes from the repository of his wisdom. The way he guides you into approaching literature is unmatched -- he will help you find artistry in even the most seemingly minor details of the work. He's also great with students -- he loves to help you with essays and is excellent in finding ways to escape writer's block. Another strength is the students -- because the course is a seminar, I learned so much from my fellow students. Each student brings a different perspective and strength in literature analysis, which creates a really rich learning environment. The books were great, but it doesn't really matter what the books are -- with this professor and with bright students, any book is worth reading.

The only qualm I had was, as a slow reader, I felt the reading was a little too rushed for me. I would prefer choosing fewer books and taking some more time on each work. Professor Peters had days exclusively on poetry between heavy books, which softened the blow a little.

Regarding the reading list: through a mix of canonical works and newer additions, the course captured both texts consider foundational and those which represent the shift of American literature in recent years. However, the class did skip Toni Morrison (which was not a big deal as I really appreciated the texts we covered); but she is so central in American Literature and we only had one other black female author in Natasha Tretheway. 

Strengths: the readings were well-paced (Moby-Dick broken over three weeks), and various, striking a meaningful dialectic of prose and poetry; the assignments too were helpfully various, helping us hone our analytical writing skills in exciting ways that encouraged radical connections rather than subsume them in narrow prompts. 

Weaknesses/for future reference: as I lover of theatre, I hope American Literature can incorporate at least one play, be it by August Wilson, Sam Shepard, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, etc. or it could incorporate an author we covered Hughes, in his collaboration with Zora Neale Hurston, "Mule Bone." Regardless of what is selected, I think the course would benefit from the third medium, to expose prospective English majors to the literary worlds and potential that plays open.

I thought the course was a great time! Professor Peters did a great job of creating a fun and supportive class atmosphere, and I always looked forward to our discussions. I enjoyed some of our break-out room sessions, and would have appreciated more variations on the standard seminar-discussion from time to time.

The strengths of this course were absolutely the people. Our seminars were undoubtedly the highlight of my week for the rich discussions that we had about complex material, as well as the bonds that we formed. Our class came to feel like a book club among friends, as we informed and critiqued each other's analyses and peer-edited each others' papers throughout the writing process. This course had no weaknesses--it was an absolute pleasure!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: John Peters gave us a little break in the middle of seminar, which I always really appreciated.
The virtual discussions succeeded.
The format was great! No problems!

Prof. Peters incorporate breakout room discussions which helped us engage with our fellow students and enabled organic discussion which resembled in-person "turning to the person next to you" interactions. 

Having a clearer structure of what passages or topics need to be covered by the end of class could've improved the holistic nature of the discussions, but ultimately our collective disproportionate focus on certain moments were always fruitful.
See above answer!
I found that the course was well adapted to the online format (although obviously it was not ideal) and cannot think of ways to improve it

Zoom is surprising for the genuine bonds that it can create over the screen. Despite the physical distance between us, my seminar connected with one another over the course of the semester, even despite the pandemic. The seminar format perfectly transferred to the medium. It was only a shame that we couldn't meet in the same classroom together every week, so we lost some of the spontaneous conversations that come with in-person discussion. Nevertheless, Professor Peters tried to recreate some of those exchanges through office hours, keeping the class going a few extra minutes for those who could stay, and an end-of-the-year virtual class dinner.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, definitely take this class is you are interested in American Literature and want a good foundation in it.
Yes! This course was phenomenal. Got to read amazing texts with wonderful people.
Yes! If you're looking for a challenge, take this class! It's very low-stress (especially Moby-Dick), but high-reward!
In a heartbeat! Great class that really taught me a lot about American Literature. Im so glad I took it.
Yes, absolutely. Take it if you relish in rich conversation and love building off your peers' insights.
Yes! This was a great overview of American literature, engaging, interesting, and improved my writing.

I would absolutely recommend American Literature to another student. Regardless of your origin, this class really investigates what it means to "American" within the context of complex histories and larger humanity through some of our country's most poignant, poetic, and philosophical voices. It is particularly refreshing in time where identity proudly as American has become increasingly complicated by recent politics.
A great introduction to American literature!
Yes, I greatly enjoyed the source material and found the writing practice/feedback useful

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. While a foundational course geared toward the English major, this class features readings and discussions that are valuable for any student. The conversations we had in this course about complex subject material made me a better thinker, literary critic, and, however cheesy (yet true) it is to say, a better American citizen. The people I encountered through this course, from my seminar mates to Professor Peters, are among the most thoughtful and empathetic students I have encountered at Yale. This seminar became the highlight of my week during an incredibly difficult semester. In my opinion, it is a must-take here at Yale.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/A
No other methods of learning
Virtual seminar. It was a class of 15 students, so we were always together; we rarely used breakout rooms.

Assigned readings and virtual seminar discussions
Breakout rooms occasionally used to focus on chapters/sections of readings
We had two virtual seminar sessions each week.
